awd_titl_txt: Telomere Roles in Fungal Genome Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine the roles that telomeres, the DNA sequences that form the ends of chromosomes, play in chromosome evolution and in making new genes. The project will study chromosome ends in the filamentous fungus Magnaporthe oryzae - a devastating pathogen of rice and wheat plants. Of the more than 20 known genes that control fungus interactions with the host plants, at least 50% are found close to the telomeres. It has long been a puzzle as to how (and why) these genes find their ways to the chromosome ends. Recent work has shown that the M. oryzae chromosome ends undergo rearrangements at spectacularly high frequencies and this can lead to the capture and duplication of internal sequences at the chromosome ends. This, in turn, causes the formerly subtelomeric sequences to be relegated to the chromosome interior. This project will use DNA sequencing and related data analysis methods to test the hypothesis that telomere dynamics is a major driver of chromosome evolution. This project largely involves DNA sequencing and associated data analysis techniques (bioinformatics). Individuals with the relevant cross-training in biology and computer science are rare and collaborations between individuals from the two domains are challenged by differences in their training and skills. Recognizing a national need for individuals with dual domain expertise, most of the objectives for this project will be completed through research experiences for teams of biology and computer science undergraduates from the partner institutions of the Univ. of Kentucky, Northern Kentucky Univ., Eastern Kentucky Univ. and Western Kentucky Univ., with specific efforts being made to enhance participation for student populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM research.

Despite intense interest in telomere biology and the importance of the associated chromosome regions (subtelomeres) in cellular biology, organismal adaptation and evolution, the organization of chromosome ends and their dynamics is poorly understood due to poor representation in genome assemblies. The central hypothesis driving this project is that the telomere regions are the main factories of fungal genome evolution, whereby recurrent bouts of telomere crisis provide the fuel for raw materials recruitment and telomere rescue pathways act to generate novel sequences. It has long been proposed that fungal genomes might evolve through such "Adaptive Telomere Failure" (ATF) but, until now, no examples had been identified. This project will greatly expand knowledge on fungal genome structure and reveal the full impact of ATF on genome organization and evolution. Additionally, it is suspected that enhanced rates of nucleotide substitution/indel polymorphism in the subtelomeric regions may further accelerate the neo-functionalization of terminally captured sequences. This project will test a number of predictions related to these hypotheses, while seeking to gain an improved understanding of subtelomere-internal genome sequence exchange, as it relates to fungal genome structure and host adaptation. Specific objectives include: 1. Generate end-to-end genome assemblies for the main host-specialized forms of M. oryzae and characterize the structural and genic diversity of the subterminal chromosome regions. 2. Assess the impact of telomere dynamics on M. oryzae genome evolution by identifying and characterizing internalized relics of former telomeres; 3. Examine genome reorganization following spontaneous or experimentally-induced telomere crisis events; and 4. Accomplish project objectives through "bite-sized" undergraduate research projects that foster collaboration between biologists and computer scientists.

por.por_cntn:
Telomeres are the DNA sequences that form the ends of eukaryotic chromosomes. They counter the loss of terminal DNA during replication, prevent chromosome end fusions and guard against exonucleolytic attack. The adjacent “subtelomere” regions are usually highly polymorphic and, in microbes, they tend to harbor families of genes involved in niche adaptation. Good examples are the substrate utilization and flocculation genes in yeast, and the variable surface protein genes of Plasmodium and Trypanosoma. It is believed that the dynamic telomere/subtelomere environment promotes variation in these genes, which provides metabolic and environmental flexibility and, in the case of the pathogens, capability to escape host recognition. Pyricularia oryzae is a devastating fungal pathogen of rice, wheat, forage crops and turf. Genes controlling interactions with the various plant hosts often map very close to the chromosome ends and we previously found that these regions undergo rearrangements at spectacularly high frequencies. It is critical to understand this telomere dynamicism because it is correlated with the fungus’ ability to defeat resistance genes that would normally prevent it from infecting important crops.

Based on our prior observations, we hypothesized that the subtelomere regions are major drivers of fungal genome evolution. We suspect that enhanced rates of DNA sequence change in the subtelomere regions may accelerate the rate at which the new gene copies acquire new functions. This project sought to test a number of predictions related to this hypothesis. Our first goal was to characterize and quantify variation in sequence composition at the chromosome ends using a large collection of Pyricularia strains. We found that only 48% of the sequences occurring adjacent to a telomere in one strain occupied a telomere-adjacent (TA) position in another strain. Instead, these sequences were very often absent and when they were present, they usually occurred near to a telomere and in the same orientation with respect to the chromosome end. This implies that chromosome ends experience frequent loss of terminal sequences, presumably due to telomere failure.

Deleting the enzymes that synthesize telomeres often results in the addition of internal sequences to the chromosome and this often occurs before terminal telomere repeats completely disappear. Searches of several genomes identified a large number of telomere repeats at interior positions within the chromosomes. These were mostly clustered near chromosome ends and were oriented in ways that implied their statuses as former telomeres that had experienced internalization after the chromosome ends had been compromised. These findings suggested that loss of telomere integrity is a common occurrence, so we developed a software tool to mine raw DNA sequence data to find new telomeres that have been added to “internal” chromosome sequences. Results from mining large datasets imply that chromosomes experience frequent breaks that are repaired by de novo telomere formation but, in many cases, lead to inviability.

To gain direct insight into the genomic consequences of telomere failure, we experimentally deleted the telomere maintenance machinery (telomerase enzyme) in several P. oryzae strains having different sequence organization at their chromosome ends. We discovered that the pathway used for repairing the chromosome ends - and the amount of time it takes a strain to recover from the resulting “telomere crisis” - is highly dependent on the sequence content of the subtelomere regions. If short tracts of telomere repeats are present, these are invaded by the critically shortened telomeres which then copy the subtelomeric sequence in an iterative fashion to produce long, tandem repeats at the chromosome ends. Chromosome ends that lack such repeats often lose subtelomeric sequence information and are either repaired by joining to other degraded ends, by invading sequences from distant chromosomal locations, or by acquiring tandem repeats from other chromosome ends that had already been repaired by D-loop formation. Intriguingly, P. oryzae strains containing transposons inserted in their telomeres were largely unaffected by telomerase deletion and the loss of subtelomeric sequence was prevented through amplification of the transposon arrays. Thus, telomeric transposons can assume telomeric functions when the normal end-maintenance mechanisms are compromised.

The final goal of our project was to provide bioinformatics research experiences for undergraduate students from the University of Kentucky and surrounding regional universities – namely the Northern, Eastern and Western Kentucky Universities. In addition, PIs Farman and Jaromczyk incorporated bioinformatics research projects into the Applied Bioinformatics course that is cross-listed in the Computer Science and Agricultural and Medical Biotechnology programs. In total, the project provided research experiences to more than 30 undergraduates as well as two graduate students. Several undergraduate and graduate student trainees are coauthors on research publications, were admitted to graduate school, or secured jobs with a bioinformatics focus.

Overall, our data point to a central role for telomeres in accelerating fungal genome evolution and suggest that enhancement of telomere integrity and reduction of starship recombination activity could reduce the fungus’ propensity to overcome resistant crop cultivars.
